Bill Venners wrote:

>  I wondered if that was you. THE Eric Armstrong.

:__))

> A recipe file contains all the ingredients and instructions needed to
> run a test. It currently includes a runpath, a set of Suites and/or
> TestCases to run, and a list of Reporters ... you can save recipes in
> files, put shortcuts to those files as icons on your desktop, then
> double click on the icons to run the tests.
>
> By next week, though, I expect to add the notion of context properties
> to the recipe...

Cool. Might context properties include a pointer to test data, as well?

> There's also a testdrivendevelopment Yahoo group:
>
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/testdrivendevelopment/

I'm on it, and still looking for the light bulb to go on. I know it will
-- there is
just some thing or another that I'm missing. (The search for
enlightenment
continues...)

BTW:
I did finally come to realize the importance of having a "lab" to help
with the design.
Basically, a lab is a unit test environment for the libraries you use,
so you can answer the questions the documents don't cover. (That concept
pretty well sold me on the concept of testability in the first place --
both to allow such laboratories, and to provide pre-defined
"experiments" that show how things work.)
